Certainly, I'll provide an exposition of James 1:1-11 verse by verse in a Markdown table format, based on the MacArthur NASB Study Bible and the ESV Study Bible by Crossway.

| Verse | Text | Explanation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | "James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, To the twelve tribes in the Dispersion: Greetings." | The author of the book is identified as James, who is believed to be the brother of Jesus. He identifies himself as a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ. He writes to the twelve tribes in the Dispersion, which refers to Jewish believers who were scattered throughout the Roman Empire due to persecution. |
| 2 | "Consider it all joy, my brethren, when you encounter various trials," | James exhorts his readers to consider it joy when they face trials. This may seem counterintuitive, but James argues that trials produce perseverance, which in turn leads to spiritual maturity. |
| 3 | "knowing that the testing of your faith produces endurance." | James explains that trials are a test of faith and produce endurance, which is necessary for spiritual growth. |
| 4 | "And let endurance have its perfect result, so that you may be perfect and complete, lacking in nothing." | James encourages his readers to let endurance have its full effect, so that they may become mature and lacking in nothing. Endurance is essential for spiritual growth and maturity. |
| 5 | "But if any of you lacks wisdom, let him ask of God, who gives to all generously and without reproach, and it will be given to him." | James tells his readers to seek wisdom from God, who gives generously to those who ask without reproach. Wisdom is essential for navigating trials and making wise decisions in life. |
| 6 | "But he must ask in faith without any doubting, for the one who doubts is like the surf of the sea, driven and tossed by the wind." | James warns that those who ask for wisdom must do so in faith, without doubting. Doubt leads to instability and wavering like waves on the sea. |
| 7 | "For that man ought not to expect that he will receive anything from the Lord," | James explains that those who doubt should not expect to receive anything from the Lord. Faith and trust are necessary for receiving from God. |
| 8 | "being a double-minded man, unstable in all his ways." | James describes a double-minded person as unstable in all his ways. A lack of faith and trust in God leads to instability and wavering. |
| 9 | "But the brother of humble circumstances is to glory in his high position;" | James encourages those in humble circumstances to glory in their position, for God exalts the humble. |
| 10 | "and the rich man is to glory in his humiliation, because like flowering grass he will pass away." | James encourages the rich to glory in their humiliation, recognizing that their wealth and status are temporary and fleeting. |
| 11 | "For the sun rises with a scorching wind and withers the grass; and its flower falls off and the beauty of its appearance is destroyed; so too the rich man in the midst of his pursuits will fade away." | James uses the metaphor of the sun and grass to illustrate the fleeting nature of wealth and status. The pursuit of riches and status is ultimately empty and fades away, like the grass that withers in the scorching sun. |
